results.title: Jewellery through 7000 years
results.brief_description: Pieces from Ancient Egypt, China, Sumeria, Greece, Celtic Europe and Byzantium, and examples of the Gothic Renaissance, Elizabethan and Art Nouveau styles are shown. Old techniques for working gold are demonstrated. Also refers to the superstitious, mythological, cultural and religious influences on jewellery design and usage.

results.title: Jets and rockets: how they work
results.brief_description: Explains the principles of jet engine propulsion by establishing Newton’s principle of action and reaction, and the principle of imbalance of forces. Discusses the varius types of fuel requirements for rockets.

results.title: Jetobatics
results.brief_description: We meet the four Royal New Zealand Air Force pilots who form New Zealand’s team of jet plane aerobats and travel in their Vampire jet aircraft while they give a magnificent display of high speed aerobatics and smoke pattern making in the sky.

results.title: Jet propulsion
results.brief_description: The film discusses the advances in aviation since the days of the Wright brothers and explains that the piston operated power unit imposes limits on the altitudes and speeds at which aircraft can fly. The basic principles of jet propulsion are outlined and the operation of a jet engine explained by means of animated diagrams. The advantages and disadvantages of jet engines are listed and different types of jet propulsion illustrated.

results.title: Jet boats in New Zealand
results.brief_description: Jet boats found in various parts of New Zealand. A New Zealand inventor demonstrates his jet boats on the beautiful lake, Manapouri; water skiers skim behind jet boats in Lyttelton Harbour; the twin jet ‘Rangimarie’ takes tourists up the Wanganui River and jet-boaters shoot the rapids and shallows of the Waimakariri River.

results.title: Jessye Norman: Singer
results.creator_credit: Cathy Palmer, Harvey Kass, Arts Council of Great Britain and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: The full range and diversity of Jessye Norman’s singing is captured on film at performances in London, Paris and New York. Examples of these performances shown are the role of Ariadne in Strauss’ Ariadne auf Naxos, and the lament from Purcell’s Dido and Aeneas. Jessye also comments on her cultural roots and evolution as a singer.

results.title: Jessye Norman Sings Carmen
results.creator_credit: Peter Gelb, Susan Froemke, Antenne-2, BBC, La Sept, Nederlandse Omroep Stichting, Philips Classics, Radio France and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description: Featuring highlights from the Philips Classics/Radio France recording of Bizet’s “Carmen”, with Jessye Norman (Carmen), Neil Shicoff (Don Jose), Simon Estes (Escamillo), Radio Chorus France, and National Orchestra of France. Filmed by Albert Maysles and Martin Schaer.

results.title: Jerusalem: within these walls
results.creator_credit: Miriam Birch, National Geographic Society and WQED
results.brief_description: Narrated by Christopher Plummer, this program offers a kaleidoscopic view and history of the city which is an important centre for three of the world’s great religions - Judaism, Christianity and Islam. The old city is divided into four quartes - Christian, Muslim, Jewish and Armenian, where about 26,000 people live. The video profiles residents of old Jerusalem including a Jewish family of Yemeni jewellers; a Belgian refugee from Nazism; a Muslim artisan and television performer, Halil; Father Timothy, private secretary to the Greek Orthodox patriarch and finally, an Armenian Christian, survivor of Turkish oppression, who now works as a photographer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Miriam Birch, National Geographic Society and WQED

results.title: Jenin Jenin
results.brief_description: Dedicated to the Executive Producer of ‘Jenin’ Iyad Samoudi who was murdered at Alyamoun at the end of the filming by Israeli soldiers on 23/6/2000. Mohammad Bakri A film of despair, human tragedy, hatred, cynicism and last but not least, of hope. This is the story of the 8 day bombardment by the Israeli Defence Forces of the autonomous Palestinian refugee camp in Jenin (Palestine) during April 2000. The camp itself was just about razed to the ground by fighter planes, tanks, missiles, and bull-dozers and all that remained at the time of filming were piles of rubble, half-demolished houses and thousands of homeless Palestinians. Many civilians including children, women and the elderly lost their lives. The older population in Jenin feel lost and defeated, betrayed by the Arab nations and the West, but at the same time they are looking to the younger generation to maintain the resistance and keep fighting for the future of all Palestinians and a free Palestinian State. Through interviews and personal stories from many of the refugees, from the young to the old, Palestinian actor/director Mohammad Bakri presents an intimate portrayal of the extent to which the prolonged oppression and terror has affected the Jenin refugees. Contains graphic archival footage (some in b&w) of the invasion and the aftermath of disaster and destruction. The film was banned in Israel for its propensity to engage in propaganda. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Jean's fugue
results.creator_credit: Michael Reeves, Derek Wright and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the activities at a Summer Music School at Cambridge. The intensive work and casual fun make the fortnight at Cambridge University benefit both the individual musician and the music world.
